2410.08852.title: Conformalized Interactive Imitation Learning: Handling Expert Shift and Intermittent Feedback
2410.08852.paper_summary:
In interactive imitation learning (IL), uncertainty quantification offers a
way for the learner (i.e. robot) to contend with distribution shifts
encountered during deployment by actively seeking additional feedback from an
expert (i.e. human) online. Prior works use mechanisms like ensemble
disagreement or Monte Carlo dropout to quantify when black-box IL policies are
uncertain; however, these approaches can lead to overconfident estimates when
faced with deployment-time distribution shifts. Instead, we contend that we
need uncertainty quantification algorithms that can leverage the expert human
feedback received during deployment time to adapt the robot's uncertainty
online. To tackle this, we draw upon online conformal prediction, a
distribution-free method for constructing prediction intervals online given a
stream of ground-truth labels. Human labels, however, are intermittent in the
interactive IL setting. Thus, from the conformal prediction side, we introduce
a novel uncertainty quantification algorithm called intermittent quantile
tracking (IQT) that leverages a probabilistic model of intermittent labels,
maintains asymptotic coverage guarantees, and empirically achieves desired
coverage levels. From the interactive IL side, we develop ConformalDAgger, a
new approach wherein the robot uses prediction intervals calibrated by IQT as a
reliable measure of deployment-time uncertainty to actively query for more
expert feedback. We compare ConformalDAgger to prior uncertainty-aware DAgger
methods in scenarios where the distribution shift is (and isn't) present
because of changes in the expert's policy. We find that in simulated and
hardware deployments on a 7DOF robotic manipulator, ConformalDAgger detects
high uncertainty when the expert shifts and increases the number of
interventions compared to baselines, allowing the robot to more quickly learn
the new behavior.
2410.08852.paper_summary_zh: <paragraph>在互動式模仿學習 (IL) 中，不確定性量化提供了一種方法，讓學習者 (即機器人) 能透過主動從專家 (即人類) 線上尋求額外的回饋，來應對部署期間遇到的分佈轉移。先前的研究使用諸如整體不一致性或蒙地卡羅輟學等機制，來量化黑盒 IL 政策在何時是不確定的；然而，這些方法在面臨部署時的分佈轉移時，可能會導致過於自信的估計。相反地，我們認為我們需要不確定性量化演算法，這些演算法可以利用在部署期間收到的專家人類回饋，來線上調整機器人的不確定性。為了解決這個問題，我們利用線上共形預測，這是一種在給定一連串的真實標籤的情況下，用於線上建構預測區間的無分佈方法。然而，在互動式 IL 設定中，人類標籤是間歇性的。因此，從共形預測的角度來看，我們引入了一種稱為間歇分位數追蹤 (IQT) 的新不確定性量化演算法，它利用間歇標籤的機率模型，維持漸近覆蓋保證，並在經驗上達到預期的覆蓋水準。從互動式 IL 的角度來看，我們開發了共形 DAgger，這是一種新的方法，其中機器人使用由 IQT 校準的預測區間，作為部署時不確定性的可靠衡量標準，以主動查詢更多專家回饋。我們在專家的政策發生變化的情況下 (以及沒有發生的情況下)，將共形 DAgger 與先前的具備不確定性感知能力的 DAgger 方法進行比較，因為分佈轉移。我們發現，在 7DOF 機器人操作器的模擬和硬體部署中，與基準相比，當專家轉移並增加干預次數時，共形 DAgger 會偵測到高度不確定性，讓機器人能夠更快地學習新的行為。</paragraph>
